awd_titl_txt: How do viscosity contrasts affect patterns of deformation in multiphase rocks?
awd_abstract_narration:
Strain in the lithosphere localizes into tabular shear zones that accommodate large amounts of tectonic strain and separate less strained portions of the lithosphere that form relatively rigid tectonic plates. Therefore, shear zones represent lithospheric-scale examples of strain partitioning that are fundamental to the architecture of the lithosphere and the operation and maintenance of plate tectonics. The idea explored here is that, due to heterogeneities in rocks, some regions will be slightly weaker then neighboring regions.  These weaker regions deform more quickly than stronger areas and, as a result, the grain size decreases in the deforming regions by a process called dynamic recrystallization.  Therefore, the strength of the initially weaker region decreases further, since strength decreases as grain size decreases.  Thus, a positive feedback loop is established in which deformation in a localized region decreases grain size which, in turn, weakens the rock in that localized region which further enhances deformation in that region. To better understand this decrease in strength with increasing amounts of deformation, the research team will deform rocks under well-controlled laboratory conditions to varying amounts of deformation. In particular, rocks composed of at least two different minerals will be studied in order to isolate the effect of one mineral on the behavior of a second mineral. A new method to quantify the internal strain of the mineral grains will be applied to data from optical and electron microscopic analysis of the experimentally-deformed samples. Ultimately, results from this study can be used to address grand challenges in the earth sciences such as what allows lithospheric plates to move past one another along narrow zones of weakness. The research project also has potential to advance desired societal outcomes through increased public scientific literacy and public engagement with STEM through various outreach activities and development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through support and mentoring of an early career post-doctoral fellow.

The central question to be addressed by this resesarch project is how different are patterns of lattice rotation axes from different phases in sheared polyphase rocks, and how do these patterns evolve during deformation? A preliminary series of laboratory torsion experiments indicate that the weaker phase reliably tracks the aggregate-scale deformation geometry, whereas the stronger phase does not. To understand this result the research team will conduct rock deformation experiments and microstructural analyses designed to test whether or not contrasts in the viscous strength of the different phases in the same rock results in systematic differences in grain-scale strain partitioning in these phases. The research will test the hypothesis that the weakest phase records the dominant rotational strain pattern. A series of new experiments will be conducted on two-phase mixtures deformed in torsion and in general shear. Torsion experiments will be conducted at a constant equivalent strain rate of 5x10-5 to 5x10-4 s-1 under constant temperature and confining pressure conditions, typically 1423 to 1523 K and 300 MPa, respectively. The torsion experiments will be used to impose a range of finite simple-shear strains on the two-phase aggregates and will be conducted to finite shear strains from 1 to 20 at shear stresses ranging from 30 to 150 MPa. General shear experiments will be conducted to finite shear strains ranging from 1 to 3 at shear stresses ranging from 30 to 100 MPa. Microstructural analyses will be conducted using electron backscatter and electron backscatter diffraction, which will provide detailed maps of all constituent phases in the deformed samples and their crystallographic orientations. The electron backscatter diffraction data will provide the foundational information necessary for quantifying lattice strain in individual grains and across entire sample sections. The internal strain within grains of the different phases will be quantified using new orientation-dispersion methods to calculate lattice-rotation patterns that will be directly compared between phases and also compared to the imposed strain geometry of each experiment. The new experiments will test the effects of viscosity and phase fraction on the development of lattice rotation patterns in three different two-phase systems. Results from analysis of large-strain torsion experiments will explore how lattice rotations in different phases develop with strain and how well rotation axes in the different phases track the deformation geometry.

por.por_cntn:
Plate tectonics is only possible on Earth because the boundaries between lithospheric plates are weak and remain weak over geologically extended periods of time.  Field observations reveal the presence of narrow regions along plate boundaries composed of fine-grained, polymineralic rocks, that is, mylonites.  Relative movement of neighboring plates is accommodated by deformation localized in these mylonitic shear zones.  For localized deformation to occur, two features of mylonites are critical - their small grain size and their polymineralic structure.  Small grain size ensures that mylonitic rocks in shear zones are weak relative to neighboring coarse-grained counterparts, and polymineralic makeup assures that mylonites remain fine-grained.  These observations motivated our research.

Polymineralic rock samples were experimentally deformed in our laboratory in torsion at high pressures and high temperatures to investigate the physical processes involved in forming fine-grained mylonites from coarse-grained rocks.  Torsion experiments are one of the few techniques available for deforming samples by large amounts, similar to conditions experienced in plate-boundary shear zones.  Specific goals were to (i) determine the strength of fine-grained rocks found in shear zones relative to the strength of neighboring coarse-grained rocks, (ii) investigate the mechanisms by which large grains transform into small grains during deformation, (iii) study mixing of newly formed small grains of one mineral with those of another mineral, and (iv) explore the process that inhibits grain growth in two-phase sample.  These results are critical for developing physically based models that are essential for applying laboratory results obtained on small samples over relatively short times to processes occurring in geologically important shear zones.

Two sets of samples were studied, one composed of the minerals olivine plus orthopyroxene and the other of olivine plus ferropericlase.  Olivine is the primary and orthopyroxene the second most abundant mineral in Earth's upper mantle; ferropericlase is well studied in both materials science and earth sciences, thus providing an excellent reference point.  In both types of samples, the proportion of the two minerals was systematically varied to test its influence on strength and post-deformation grain size.

In olivine-rich samples, strength continually deceased with increasing amount of deformation.  Associated with high-strain deformation, grain sizes of both phases decreased.  Quantitatively, strength decreased by a factor of more than 30, if grain size decreased by a factor of 10.  Thus, a strong contrast in strength developed between the fine-grain mylonite produced by deformation and the coarse-grained starting sample, a key ingredient in formation of ductile shear zones in experiments and in Earth.  Detailed scanning electron microcopy analyses of deformed samples revealed that grain size decreased due to dynamic recrystallization.  In addition, grains of the two minerals became thoroughly mixed during deformation. 

Two results from our deformation experiments are critical to understanding formation and longevity of shear zones.  First, grain size in deformed polymineralic samples is a factor of ~10 smaller than in deformed samples composed of only olivine.  Second, during subsequent static annealing, no grain growth occurred in bi-mineralic samples, in contrast to olivine-only samples in which grains grew rapidly.  Grain growth is inhibited in bi-mineralic samples because grains of one mineral impede the migration of interfaces that separate grains of the other mineral from one another.  This process, known as Zener pinning, results in a specific relationship between the grain sizes of the two minerals; namely, the ratio of the size of grains of the more abundant phase to that of the less abundant phase is inversely proportional to the amount of the less abundant phase.  This correlation, known as the Zener relationship, describes samples deformed under laboratory conditions as well as rocks deformed by mother nature, thus permitting direct application of experimental results to determining the behavior of rocks collected from large shear zones along plate boundaries. 

To test our hypothesis that shear zones develop in regions composed of two or more minerals, we carried out a series of experiments on layered samples.  Alternate layers were composed of olivine and olivine plus ferropericlase; initial grain size was the same in all layers.  As the experiment proceeded, deformation localized in bi-mineralic layers.  Examination of microstructures of layers after deformation, revealed that grain size in olivine plus ferropericlase layers was smaller than in olivine-only layers.  The difference resulted because Zener pinning inhibited grain growth when more than one mineral was present.

To summarize, the presence of fine-grained mylonites in lithospheric shear zones is an important clue concerning the reason for localization of deformation and the cause of shear-zone longevity.  Our laboratory experiments quantified this behavior by demonstrating that polymineralic rocks are weaker than single-mineral samples because of the smaller grain size of the former.  In addition, grain-scale mixing of two phases during deformation is critical to preventing grain growth because of Zener pinning, which maintains and even further refines this small grain size, thus establishing shear zones with geological lifetimes.
